headline: CNN Live Event/Special
subHeadline: Being Chris Sununu; Governor Sununu Not Running For President; Donald Trump Lost His Charisma. Aired 10-11p ET

utterances.speaker: DANA BASH, CNN ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: What's it like being governor of a critical swing state who won big on an otherwise underwhelming election night for the GOP?GOV. CHRIS SUNUNU (R-NH):  I see it as an opportunity. Where are we going to take our message? What can we do better?

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: In a party conflicted about its identity.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: It's hard to tell someone that the best opportunity for new leadership is yesterday's leadership.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Could New Hampshire's Chris Sununu have a winning formula for Republicans?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: You know the key to politics is? Be normal. That's it.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: A busy dad --

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Valerie and the kids keep it so real and so grounded for me.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: -- who's defining his own role within a political family dynasty, a rising Republican star who has managed to avoid the former president's ire even when speaking out against him.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: I'm just telling you, if you can't say stuff like that, I'm going to push back.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Soon facing a major decision about his future.Are you thinking about running for president in 2024? In this series we talk to people in politics and pop culture and find out what it's like to be them. Now Being Chris Sununu. You were just re-elected, a Republican governor in a purple state. So, what's it like to be you right now given the fact you're a Republican at a very interesting time for the GOP?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: I see it as an opportunity.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: How?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: A great opportunity, on opportunity to say, okay, where are we going to take our message, what can we do better? I think the opportunity is, you know, helping potential candidates, hopefully inspiring the next generation of Republicans to step up, hopefully inspiring folks to realize it isn't as partisan as maybe the last few years have really been. It doesn't have to be that way. And voters don't want it that way. And so we have an opportunity to kind of embrace that and go forward with good Republican conservative ideals to get more stuff done.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: The midterm election was not the red wave a lot of Republicans predicted. Why?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Bad candidates. Yes, we did not have the right candidates that came out of a lot of our primaries, and I think they lost sense of the priorities of the Republican Party, of the independent voter, just the extremism, the election denial, all of that stuff.And I think the Democrats did a wonderful job of predefining our candidates before they could introduce themselves.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Sununu defines himself in a way most Republicans do not.Where are you on the Republican spectrum?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: All over the place.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Yes. When you say extreme, so how would you define yourself?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: I just think I try to be as normal and genuine as I can be. I don't change my philosophies. I don't change my principles or what I'm about, but I try to be very approachable and I try to be very data- based.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Are you a moderate?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: On social issues, I'm more moderate than other Republicans. On fiscal issues, I'm much more conservative and I'm very proud of that.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: He won a fourth term as governor of New Hampshire by more than 15 percentage points, but all three federal GOP candidates there lost.So, the lesson is they were the wrong candidates because they were too extreme?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: For this state, yes, absolutely, yes. I mean, I supported them.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: I know you did.Candidates like election denier Don Bolduc, whom Sununu did not support in the primary.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: He's not a serious candidate. I mean, he's really not. He's kind of a conspiracy theorist-type candidate.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: But he backed the GOP Senate candidate in the general election.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: He wants to makes things up and he's going to go down to Washington and do that.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: When we talked before the election, Sununu was confident.Senate race?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Right now, Maggie Hassan is ahead.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: What's your prediction?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: I think Bolduc wins. Yes, Don Bolduc is --

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: That's a bold prediction.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Not if you know the state.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Bolduc lost by over 9 percentage points.When you and I talked in October, you said that the Republicans were going to win here.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: He says he wants to see his party move off that path away from lies and conspiracy theories embraced by the former president. Many voters seem to agree. Most of the candidates Trump endorsed in key House and Senate races lost in November.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: He did not have a very good record, to be sure.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: What does that tell you?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: That he is not the influence he thinks he is. That's when the former president announced that he's running for president a week after the election, everyone were like, okay.DONALT TRUMP, FORMER U.S. PRESIDENT:  In order to make America great and glorious again, I am tonight announcing my candidacy for the president of the United States.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: He's announcing he's running for president at his most politically weak point. He's doing it from a point of weakness, from a point of whatever his own agenda is. But it's kind of just a blip on the radar. There's an argument to be made he's not even the frontrunner, right?

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Sununu always had a unique relationship with Trump, critical at times.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: We know the president has a tendency to speak in hyperbole and tweet things out and all that stuff.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: But do you like to have the former president campaign with you in your re-election campaign in New Hampshire?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: I don't need anyone to campaign with me.Donald Trump does not define Chris Sununu. He doesn't even define the Republican Party.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: But he somehow escaped Trump's counterpunch.You've managed to walk this line that most Republicans have not. How?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Well, you know, early on when he became president, we made it really clear, both with him, we had a relationship and with the White House, that, look, when he does things with policy and whatever, if he does things that deserves credit, I'll be the first one to stand up and give him credit. But when you have a tone or something that I disagree with, or he says things or does things I disagree with. I'm going to say that too.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: The joke heard around the world of American politics.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: Chris Sununu is clarifying a comment that he made over the weekend about former President Trump.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE
utterances.sentences: You made some comments that did raise a lot of eyebrows and got some headlines as well.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: You addressed a ballroom full of journalists and top Washington elected officials in both parties, and you called Donald Trump (BLEEP) crazy. Do you think he is effing crazy?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: It's a good joke. Yes. Look, it's a roast, let's be honest, the gridiron dinner is a roast.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: The part of a roast is that there's more than a grain of truth to a lot of things that he says.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: That's how good comedy is and -

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: But do you think that's what he is?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: He has a style unto himself. I'm going to be as polite as I can be.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.sentences: We were getting ready to win this election. Frankly, we did win this election.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: The conspiracies, the, frankly, lies that he pedaled about the election and then what happened on January 6th, is he fit to be president again?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: I just don't think he's going to be president again.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: But do you think he should be president again?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: No. Because he's done his time, he's done his service, we're moving on. We are. As a country as a party, we want the next idea, we want the next generation, whatever it is. So, to say we're going to be a country where the best opportunity for our future leadership is the leadership of yesterday, that's, frankly, un-American. We're just taking the next step. We're moving on. Thank you for your service, we're moving on.GOV. RON DESANTIS (R-FL):  Thank you for a historic landslide victory.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: He even brought up Florida Governor Ron DeSantis unprompted as a stronger potential candidate than Trump.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: There's an argument to be made that someone like DeSantis could beat him in a primary today. And this --

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Do you think he could?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: I think another candidate could, yes. Do I think DeSantis? Maybe. I don't know. I mean, I really don't know.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Would he be a good president?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: I think he would be a good president, sure. I think a lot of Republican governors would be good --

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Do you think that he would be able to connect with voters the way you're describing?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Everyone connects with voters differently, right? I mean, I don't want to speak specifically to Ron but I have my style, he has his style. Everyone is a little different. Every state is different.Every single vote matters, and that's what we saw today, huge turnout, everyone participating in the process.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Sununu is not shy about wanting to take part in reshaping his national party. SUNUNUSo, both myself and others will, I think, be driving this message. And then through that process you see who can stand up and meet that message, that can meet that challenge to be a leader with those qualities, those intangibles, those communication skills, those policies we want to see.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: But does Sununu want to be the ultimate Republican leader?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Look, I'm not trying to be coy. I'm really not.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: I brought some of these skeletons but all the cemetery stuff I made my hand.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: -- the governor gets on the roof and behind a wheel.(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Being a Sununu in New Hampshire is all about the family business, politics.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Welcome.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Wow. So, this is the governor's office.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: This is it.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: What's it like to be here as governor? You would run around here as a kid.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: It's the same place. I mean, everything is really the same. I mean, the portraits may be a little different or they've upgraded the furniture, I suppose, a little bit. But now, it's really the same place.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Each day when he walks into his office at the statehouse, he's greeted by a portrait of his father, former New Hampshire Governor John Sununu.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: But this is amazing portrait.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: But you're in that. You're back there, right? SUNUNU

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Not only are there two governors in the family, his older brother, John E. Sununu, represented New Hampshire in the House and Senate from 1997 to 2009, big shoes to fill for Chris, the seventh of eight kids.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Back when those computers were coming in.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Exactly. So, how do I craft that to more of a 2022 style message or policy? He was one of those who wanted to stay very connected to the constituency. He was very hands on. He spent so much time out of this office. And that was an amazing lesson I learned very early on about the --

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Because you watched that when you were young?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Watched it, participated in it, everything.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: In 1989 when he was 14, his father became White House Chief of Staff to President George H.W. Bush. He remembers it as a tough time.He was governor. He left. You went to the Washington, D.C. area. That was not -- your eyes are getting big.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Pleasant. That was not pleasant.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: It was not pleasant.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: No, it's different. I remember walking in my freshman year and kids are sitting kind of at their lockers early morning, waiting for class to start. And they're reading The Washington Post. I'm like this is a bizarre world. But given that my dad, our federal policy was at the front of a lot of those discussions, it just made it very awkward, a very tough time. And it never got quite unawkward.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Those headlines got tougher when his father became embroiled in controversy and eventually left the Bush White House. SUNUNU

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Until he did. His office is the same one his dad used more than 30 years ago. But Sununu says his political inspiration actually came from his other parent.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: My mom was on the school board, I think, before my dad even got involved in politics. I mean, that was really my intro to politics. My mom would bring us over to the library, Kelly Library in Salem, New Hampshire. I'd sit on the floor and call her while the school board meeting was going on in the bottom of the library and then would go. But that was the whole process, you got to -- you tied your time. And if you have eight kids, here's a good idea, get on the school board.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Yes. Sununu and his wife, Valerie, are now raising three children of their own. He says he makes a point to build family time into his schedule, even hanging homemade Halloween decorations.This is no joke.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: This is pretty amazing.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Again, probably started a few years ago as a way of me just getting outside, a real little therapy, if you will. I made a lot of it on my own. I bought some of these skeletons, but like all these cemetery stuff I made by hand, and I was just trying to be handy to get my mind off stuff.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: The wood on the windows?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: And this is your project?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: This is my thing.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Do you ever enlist the kids? No? You just do it on your own?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Yes, they like it. Yes, they enjoy it. They really -- it's Halloween. My kids love Halloween. And it's New England. I mean, everyone in New England loves Halloween. So, I don't know. I'm sure there's some -- someone could do some psychoanalysis on why the governor loves Halloween and obsesses over --

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Your next therapy appointment, get back to me and tell me what your therapist says.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Right here. That's my therapist.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: This is your therapist? Hello. SUNUNU

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: 2024, are you kidding?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: No way. And there goes my political career.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: His youngest son, Leo, is nine years old, the same age he was when his dad was governor.Are there things that you experienced that you said, oh, boy, I don't want him to go through that?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Yes, yes. If they don't want to do a parade, I don't make them go to a parade.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Did you have to go to parades?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: All the time, yes. But I didn't mind it. I really tries to respect the fact that because of the social media and all these other pressures that I didn't have, they have them, and they're -- I give them as much flexibility to walk their path. If they want to come to a cool event, great, and if not, that's fine, too.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Right. So, you could walk in a parade in 1980-something and maybe it would be on the local news and that was it.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Now, it's on everybody's --

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Social media, whatever.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: So, they can't have anonymity, like you could.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: No, there's very little for a family.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: How does your family like you being governor?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: It's hard. They like it. I mean, I wouldn't say like or not like. Maybe that's not the right word, but it's hard on them, and especially during the pandemic. It could be brutal at times. But I don't think either of us can truly appreciate what kids have to deal with, everything from bullying, from sometimes directly, sometimes indirectly. It can come from students, it can come from teachers, it can come from strangers. And it can be based on something real, it can be based on misinformation, it can be based on emotion. So --

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: But they have a giant white hot spotlight on them because of who you are?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Yes. I think almost anybody in my position does.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Your wife is very private.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Yes. BASH

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: When she married you, she knew that you had politicians in your family. When you said, oh, honey, I think I'm going to run for office.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Yes, and she said, no, you're not. And I said, yes, I knew that was coming. But then we talked about it. She got behind it 100 percent, God bless her. Very unknown for her. I kind to knew what I was getting into somewhat. I knew what the kids were getting into somewhat, very unknown for her but she was very supportive. And I'm blessed to have that, that kind of support.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: The governor does find ways to unwind outside of his busy schedule. Taking rides in his 1966 Mustang convertible, a vintage car he's had since he was a teenager, top down --

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: If you think I'm not turning a (INAUDIBLE) in this car.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Music cranked.If you don't do it, I will. Coming up, the governor opens up about a life changing health scare.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Being Chris Sununu means leaving and breathing New Hampshire.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: I just love it here. My family is here. I'm probably addicted to this state almost to a fault. And if you're in a place like New Hampshire, there's no better thing to do than go hiking especially at this time of year.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Of course, the sound of the leaves under your feet.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: I love it. It's like a rhythmic meditation.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Yes?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Yes. You're kind of going through like swoosh, swoosh, swoosh, and you're kind of -- it's very common.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: The four-term Granite State governor had a long journey to get to politics starting with a more than 2,000-mile hike after graduating from MIT.The Appalachian Trail?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Is that how you got the bug for hiking?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Probably, yes. So, I just love being outdoors. I've worked really hard at MIT. It was a tough 4, 4.5 years. As we say in New Hampshire, it was wicked hot. It was wicked hot. So, I just wanted to make sure I was taking the right first steps, sort to saying, what better way to do that than to kind to see what it was like go live in the woods for five months and hike 2,000 miles.The idea of starting on one mountain and end up in Maine and end up in Georgia was pretty exciting. And just -- it's a personal challenge. I'm kind of goal-oriented. Very few people actually start and are able to finish. Let's see if we can do this. And maybe we learn a little something about ourselves and --

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: What did you learn about yourselves?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Priorities. When you're worried about where to get a drink of water every day for five months, it kind of puts things in perspective when you come back to the real world in terms of priorities, needs, what's important, what isn't, what you should spend your time on worrying about. And that's what the Appalachian Trail. It gave me a great perspective.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Perspective that not everything should be at an 11?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Exactly. Exactly.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: After college, Sununu, spent a decade as an environmental engineer before stepping into unexpected role he says prepared him for the governorship.But, first of all, how did you get from MIT, engineer to, oh, I'm going to buy and manage a ski a resort?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: I worked as a business consultant, helped some folks out that wanted to buy a ski resort. We ended up driving the whole process. And I found the investors for this group and all the investors said, okay, we're going to invest but we want you to run it. And I said, well, what do I know about running a ski resort? They said, well, who wrote the business plan? I said, I did. That's what we want you to do. We believe in the plan. This is the right path. It's a little different. This is what we want. Next day, I am running a resort.All of those aspects of running a business, as stressful as they were, as challenging, amazing learning experience. And that's one of the things that got me to run for governor. I said, well, we've learned a lot, we've kind of trialed by fire in a lot of these things. We've designed new systems, we have taken on new challenges, that's good management and expertise. And it's exactly what I thought the state needed at the time.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: So, that CEO management experience was absolutely the best training for this job?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: It's the only training. And I'm quite a big believer in that. If you haven't had the sweat out payroll to take care of your employees and their families, if you haven't had to work with shareholders or folks that are coming to you to manage their money, I mean, there's no greater responsibility in government than managing other people's money, none.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Last summer, he was forced to slow down when a serious health scare sent him to the hospital.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: I thought I had COVID. And I was just exhausted all day for about a week. And then I thought the holiday weekend of Labor Day of '21 is coming up, I'd better go in and just checked it out. And sure enough, I'd been bleeding inside all week. I had a bleeding ulcer. I only had about a third of my blood level, the way they should be, and they had to start the transfusions immediately. And, again, I thought I had a flu or COVID. The next thing I know, I got four transfusions over a period of 24 hours. They saved me, it was great.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Saved you, like --

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Yes. Well, if they said, ultimately, you probably just would have fallen asleep and not woken up, and you would have never known because I was bleeding out essentially. So, it was kind of scary because I'm 47. I like to consider myself like 26, but I am 47.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: But 47 is young to have a health scare like that.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: It is. It is. And so you've got to manage your stress. Everybody does.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: I was just going to say, you know what ulcers tend to be from, right?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Yes, I know. I know. It's -- look, it's a stressful job and we had just come through the COVID pandemic. And I think we did great.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: So, it affected you physically?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: The now 48-year-old says the lifesaving procedure gave him perspective.

utterances.speaker: REPORTER
utterances.sentences: He arrived here by ambulance just before 2

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: When I saw that image, it hit home.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Really?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Oh, it was a very scary looking image.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Because it quite literally took you out of your--

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: I was in a gurney and they had all the tubes in me and they're giving me blood as they-- it's a scary looking thing and I'm like, who's that guy? I'm like, oh my God, that's me.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: But that is what gave you the aha moment.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Yes, I had to see myself on the outside.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Oh, my God.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Going oh, my holy cow. And then I said, wow, this is pretty serious. Pretty serious. It was very scary. It was. And you try to learn from it, hopefully learn from it, change habits. I mean - well, a little bit. No, I definitely learned from it.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: What did you learn?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Sometimes it's OK to put yourself first. Sometimes it's OK for health reasons. Because--

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: And how have you done that?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: How do I want to do it? How do I plan on doing it.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: What's your aspirational?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Physical health is important. Right? So, maybe losing a few pounds and getting out and running more, not just--

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: (Inaudible) differently.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: I try to, I'm trying to eat a little less meat, a little less red meat. And--

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Because of your bleeding ulcer.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Because of that, and because Tom Brady said so, I love Tom Brady. Pretty much what Tom Brady says I want to aspire to. And I go to bed at night going oh, I shouldn't have eaten that cookie dough. Right? Like 20 minutes ago, probably. Tom Brady wouldn't have eaten raw cookie dough at 10

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Are you trying to follow the Tom Brady diet? SUNUNU

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Tom Brady may be the aspiration, but for now Sununu says he's just looking for balance.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Yes, I carry a lot of stress with me. There's no doubt about that. I grew up in a big family. You kind of took care of yourself, right? You fell down and scraped your knee, you got up, you rub dirt on it, you got back out there, that's just the way we did it. And so, I guess emotionally and mentally in terms of dealing with stresses, I tend to have that same pattern. But as you get older, it's not necessarily the best thing and the healthiest thing to do. And I want to be here for my kids and I want to be here for the state and I've got a job to do, it doesn't help me doesn't help the state if I'm laid up.That was the one scare that I really had. I've been pretty blessed but you've got to learn from it and hopefully take better habits and move on.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Up next, the governor presses the flesh across New Hampshire.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Great to see you. I'm doing great.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: But could he ever leaves the Granite State? This is absolutely beautiful.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Hi, New Hampshire Governor Chris Sununu will join us in just a couple of moments. He's live in studio with us today.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Being Chris Sununu means getting up early and getting out front during the final weeks of his 2022 reelection campaign.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: As a candidate, whether it's for governor or the school board. You've got to be - what am I bringing to the table?

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: He redefines the term boundless energy from radio stations to rotary clubs, small town streets and local watering holes.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Numbers in America. BASH(VIDEO PLAYING)

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: He says he fell in love with country music during COVID and reworked that Johnny Cash song during his campaign. You wrote that?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: I wrote the whole song myself, just one night sitting at home.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Wow.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: And then it sat at my desk and I just didn't like as a fun little game in my head part.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Do you remember the words? You'd have get to go through--

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: (Inaudible) I could. The video does look pretty cool. And it made me realize that I took a lot of selfies. I take a lot of selfies.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: It's like no one ask for autographs anymore. It's just selfies.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: That's the new autograph, which is cool.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: We joined him for a day of events as he crisscrossed the state. You're always in governor mode.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Always thinking, yes, it's hard. Look, I just have to manage Medicaid. I have to manage veterans' benefits. I have to manage all these big-ticket things. But at the same time, so much of our success is driven on a local economy, small business. How are these folks doing? Do they have workforce? Where does their workforce live? Do we have the opportunity for new housing project, we can talk about how great New Hampshire is and all the great statistics. But at the end of the day, the real issue is tell me what's wrong. Tell me what isn't working, right. Because now I got the challenge to go and kind of fix it or try to break down the barrier, figure out how to make it better. That's the funniest part of the job.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Hard to believe he insists he was once a shy introvert.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Hey, Chris. Pleasure. Nice to see you.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: Nice to see you.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.sentences: I just turned 95 last week.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: That's it.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Between campaign stops, we followed him on a grocery run.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: All right, so I do need a few things.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: A regular errand he insists he enjoys.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: This would have been - sort of have been just under four bucks about a year ago. BASH

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Therapy? I love it. So first, I'm a math guy. So, I have my budget in my head. We're going to spend 125 bucks; I've got to get the best deals. And I find I like doing it. I just I enjoy it.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: But this is really therapy - like is this - this is not just for us.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Oh, I love it. No, no, no. Oh, no, no, no, I'm here all the time. And again, Valerie (ph) comes into shopping. But I'll be like, no, no, let me go. I'd rather go.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: A chance to see firsthand how much things cost and for constituents to come up and say hi.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Nice to see you. Have you been? Nice to see you, I'm doing great.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: It's therapy, but is it also--

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: It's my time--

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: To interact.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: He's very open that he hopes his down to earth approach rubs off on the younger generation now more familiar with toxic political styles.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: I think one of the opportunities we have is with, I'll say, the 35 and unders, 32 and under right year-old demographic, those are excited animated voters, they want to get involved. But they've really only seen and participated in politics at its most littoral level, like nobody gets inspired to get more involved in public service by being yelled at or blasted out from a podium or shaking their feet. No one gets inspired by that, they might get amped up, but not inspired.And I think real leadership has an opportunity, especially with the younger generation to inspire them, show that that higher path, if you will, that opportunity that they have to be positive, to be - to work with the other side.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: I don't know if you've noticed, but some of our leaders are not young.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: That's politically correct term.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Is it time for a younger generation, a new generation of leaders, does that make a difference?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Well, I think it's always - it's always good to get young folks that come in with energy. But you do need experience too. When I became governor at 42, I was shocked when they told me I was the youngest governor in the country. And I was the youngest for like four years. And I'm like, really, there's obviously has been some older leadership. There's nothing wrong with that, if it comes with the right tone and the right approach and, and using the right experiences, theoretically, the older, wiser you are, you should have more experience to not get emotional over a political issue, to not get amped up and triggered and overcharged on the political side of things, actually, hopefully bring some experience some maturity, some calmness, understand the value of deescalating a situation before it gets so hyped up that you can't negotiate anymore.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: A lot of Republicans lobbied Sununu to run for Senate in 2022. But he said his love for being governor, a chief executive, not a legislator made it easy to turn down.You didn't want to leave this and go to Washington to represent the state in the Senate, because you wanted to see the seeds that you plan to actually grow?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Yes, I am a manager, right? We were designing new systems here, new ways to do it.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: But isn't that a part of you that wants to sprinkle those seeds--

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Of course.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Over 49 other states.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Yes, I'm very proud of what we've done here. And I do I travel--

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: There's a way that you can do that.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Well, I try. There's a lot of ways to do that.But BASH: there's one way that you can be the CEO of all of America.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Everyone, woke up.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: On election day being Chris Sununu met getting in those last few moments with voters and the press.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: We've worked really hard. We've made sure folks just talk about the issues, understand our record of success.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Casting his ballot and thanking supporters.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Are you excited?

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: I am.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Very good.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: This arcade is Sununu's election night campaign headquarters.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Hey, buddy. Hey, you want me to sign it.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Hey, thanks for coming, guys.

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: Can I take a picture with you?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Of course, yes, yes.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Complete with bowling, video games, and even ax throwing. And then the moment of truth.(CROWD CHANTING)

utterances.speaker: UNKNOWN
utterances.sentences: We have three projections to bring you, all three of them Republican holds beginning in the state of New Hampshire. Chris Sununu winning a fourth term.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: This is awesome.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: While Sununu was victorious in New Hampshire, Republicans nationwide did not fare as well.One of the main messages we heard from President Biden and other Democrats was democracy is on the ballot. Was democracy on the ballot?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: The system was on the ballot. Right? The system, the partisanship was on the ballot. I don't like the term democracy because what that means, he's saying is if you vote for Republicans, you're not with demo -- that that's not a fair assessment. BASHdenies the results of the election, that's not democratic.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Do you?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: How do you know?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Because they said it to his face during the primary that he was an out touch old white guy that did not represent the future of the Democrat Party.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Just purely for a political reason, as a Republican, do you want him to run?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: No. I just don't think it's good for America. I think it's good -- I think it's good on both sides to get a lot of moving forward fresh blood there. Yes. Fresh ideas.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Fresh blood and ideas.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: I, Christopher T. Sununu --

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Is he referring to himself? At the State House in Concord his office is just steps away from the Secretary of State's office where presidential candidates registered to be on the ballot for New Hampshire's famous primary.So, if you were to run for president, you would walk out that door, walk down this hallway, and all you have to do is go right there.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Probably just do it on my lunch break at some point. I wouldn't tell anyone.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: You do have an advantage if in the future you decide to cross this threshold and actually sign it because this is the first the nation primary state.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Yes. But not as much as you think.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Really?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Yes, because being governor is very different, you know, than being president. Their -- the responsibilities vary differently and I think our voters appreciate that. So, I imagine anybody if from their home state, whether it's a couple candidates in South Carolina or a few candidates down in Florida, you're still going to have to earn it one way or the other. You can't take anything for, for granted.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: So, will he make that walk to run?Are you thinking about running for president in 2024?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: No. I'm not thinking about it right now. I'm really not.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Right now.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Well, not ever technically. I haven't -- I haven't. I haven't. Look, folks have talked to me about it, that's obvious and clear. And I think as things start gearing up into '23 more folks will be talking about it. My focus right now is New Hampshire. It really is. Because it has to be and I want it to be.I mean, we have our challenge. But we also have amazing results to back up the systems that we've put into place at a local level. People ask me to travel the country all the time. How are you doing it in New Hampshire? How do you have no sales tax and income tax, but all this economic success? Why? Why are you guys the ones growing so aggressively in the northeast? And if that can be, you know, copied across the country and inspire our next generation to know that not everything has to be, you know, fire branded on both sides, that's a win for America.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: It sounds like what you're saying is you want to be a model nationally. You don't want to be a candidate for president.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: I want -- we want to be a model nationally. And I want to share that record of success.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: It's so funny you didn't answer the second part of my question.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: I was just getting to it, but you interrupted. So, we'll go into the next thing. No, I'm not.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Are you open to it?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: I'm open to everything, of course. Look, I'm open to what comes in that door next. I'm open to any opportunity that might come down the road. Not for me personally, but for the state and the community.(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: It sounds like a cooking opportunity. You said people are coming up to you.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: It could be down the road, but nothing I'm really focusing on today.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Today like 2024, because you're young.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Today isn't 2024.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: No. Meaning, meaning in this cycle?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Yes. Gee, look, I'm not trying to be coy. I'm really not. I'm just --(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: You kind of, are.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: No, I'm not. I'm just -- I can tell you part of my job is being ready for whatever comes next.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Sununu insist Donald Trump's announcement will not influence his decision or any other potential 2024 challenger.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: It shouldn't be about what, what somebody else is there. And as I said, he's not at a political -- a point of political strength right now. I don't think it's going to be going up. I think it's unfortunately for the former president, it's only probably a slow downward spiral from here.Could he still win the nomination? Absolutely. Let's not fool ourselves of that. But he's not going to keep anybody out of this race.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: One of the ways he could still win the nomination is one of the ways he won in 2016, which is there is a huge field of candidates and they segment or fragment the voters. And then he takes the nomination --(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: With 35 percent.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: -- with even -- he could even do less than 35 percent.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Is there any conversation that is going on should go on to say, in order to stop Donald Trump, we need to not all jump in. We need to pick somebody the best candidate and run that way.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: No, not -- not, I think a lot of us are looking at governors that may run, and I think as governors, we all want to see a governor run and be successful.Governors are executives. I always say the Senate, U.S. Senate and Congress has its place, but they're not -- they don't have executive leadership skills.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: On the notion of getting together and having a conversation. Obviously, it hasn't happened yet.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Yes. Like do we presort ourselves out?

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Should it? Should that happen?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: No. No, because it's up to the voters, not to the establishment elite to decide who's going to be --(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Well, it's not necessarily elite.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: I think all the -- I think, I've -- just speaking to the folks I've talked to that might be elected officials, I think everyone understands that there's that obligation responsibility. If it's not happening, it's not happening. You got to get out there.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: But you got to get in first.People look at you and they say, he can be a guy who I could see running.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Yes, that's very flattering. I'm proud. Look, that tells me we're getting good results and we have the right approach. And it's not just about Chris Sununu's here.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Is it flattering or is it enticing?

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: No, it's flattering. Look, there's a lot of downsides with being president of the United States. There's the whole living in a bubble and all that kind, and you do that to a certain extent in New Hampshire. But boy, I can still say, stay so connected to my constituents and that's probably a lot harder to do as president. And so that's a, a factor. How does it affect my family --(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: And also, somebody who likes a challenge.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: I love challenges. I love redesigning systems. I love taking new ideas on.

utterances.speaker: BASH
utterances.sentences: Would you like to redesign America.

utterances.speaker: SUNUNU
utterances.sentences: Look, I would love the challenge of being part of something that can redesign a better system, because whatever is going on in Washington is not working.
